KOTTAYAM

Kottayam

is a district in the south-western part of Kerala that offers a variety of attractions for tourists. It is known for its natural beauty, historical heritage, and cultural diversity. Here are some of the tourist attractions in Kottayam district that you can visit:

Kumarakom

This is one of the most popular places around Kottayam, mainly due to its scenic backwaters and bird sanctuary. Kumarakom is a cluster of islands on the Vembanad Lake, and offers a serene and relaxing experience. You can enjoy a cruise on a traditional houseboat, or a kettuvallam, and witness the rural life, lush greenery, and diverse wildlife along the banks. You can also visit the Kumarakom Bird Sanctuary, which is home to various species of birds, such as herons, egrets, kingfishers, and cuckoos. You can also spot migratory birds, such as Siberian cranes, during the winter season

Ilaveezhapoonchira

This is a hill station and a picnic spot near Melukavumattom, about 55 km from Kottayam. It is famous for its panoramic view of the surrounding hills and valleys. The name of the place means “the valley where leaves do not fall”, as there are no trees on the hills. It is also a great place to watch the sunrise and the sunset. You can also trek to the nearby hills, such as Mankunnu, Kudayathoormala, and Thonippara

Poonjar Palace

This is a historical palace and museum, built by the Poonjar Rajas, who ruled the region for centuries. The palace is a fine example of the Kerala style of architecture, and has a wooden structure, with intricate carvings and paintings. The museum displays various artifacts, such as weapons, furniture, lamps, statues, and coins, belonging to the royal family and the Travancore Kingdom. The palace also has a replica of the Madurai Meenakshi Temple, and a huge chandelier gifted by the Belgian king

Vagamon

This is another hill station and a summer resort, located at an altitude of 1100 meters above sea level. It is a place of tranquility and serenity, with lush green meadows, pine forests, waterfalls, and misty valleys. You can also visit the Kurisumala Ashram, a Christian monastery that follows the Indian traditions of meditation and yoga. You can also indulge in some adventure activities, such as paragliding, trekking, and rock climbing
